messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the llvm-project program, here is the asan report

This is an LLVM error report. Please refer the error message for more details.

clang-21: /tmp/llvm-gh-137276/build/clang/lib/CodeGen/CodeGenTypes.cpp:853: bool clang::CodeGen::CodeGenTypes::isPointerZeroInitializable(clang::QualType): Assertion `(T->isAnyPointerType() || T->isBlockPointerType()) && "Invalid type"' failed.
Stack dump:
0. 1.	<eof> parser at end of file

The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 2100 to line 2160 in clang/lib/CodeGen/CGExprAgg.cpp:
2100| /// GetNumNonZeroBytesInInit - Get an approximate count of the number of
2101| /// non-zero bytes that will be stored when outputting the initializer for the
2102| /// specified initializer expression.
2103| static CharUnits GetNumNonZeroBytesInInit(const Expr *E, CodeGenFunction &CGF) {
2104|   if (auto *MTE = dyn_cast<MaterializeTemporaryExpr>(E))
2105|     E = MTE->getSubExpr();
2106|   E = E->IgnoreParenNoopCasts(CGF.getContext());
2107| 
2108|   // 0 and 0.0 won't require any non-zero stores!
2109|   if (isSimpleZero(E, CGF)) return CharUnits::Zero();
2110| 
2111|   // If this is an initlist expr, sum up the size of sizes of the (present)
2112|   // elements.  If this is something weird, assume the whole thing is non-zero.
2113|   const InitListExpr *ILE = dyn_cast<InitListExpr>(E);
2114|   while (ILE && ILE->isTransparent())
2115|     ILE = dyn_cast<InitListExpr>(ILE->getInit(0));
2116|   if (!ILE || !CGF.getTypes().isZeroInitializable(ILE->getType()))
2117|     return CGF.getContext().getTypeSizeInChars(E->getType());
2118| 
2119|   // InitListExprs for structs have to be handled carefully.  If there are
2120|   // reference members, we need to consider the size of the reference, not the
2121|   // referencee.  InitListExprs for unions and arrays can't have references.
2122|   if (const RecordType *RT = E->getType()->getAs<RecordType>()) {
2123|     if (!RT->isUnionType()) {
2124|       RecordDecl *SD = RT->getDecl();
2125|       CharUnits NumNonZeroBytes = CharUnits::Zero();
2126| 
2127|       unsigned ILEElement = 0;
2128|       if (auto *CXXRD = dyn_cast<CXXRecordDecl>(SD))
2129|         while (ILEElement != CXXRD->getNumBases())
2130|           NumNonZeroBytes +=
2131|               GetNumNonZeroBytesInInit(ILE->getInit(ILEElement++), CGF);
2132|       for (const auto *Field : SD->fields()) {
2133|         // We're done once we hit the flexible array member or run out of
2134|         // InitListExpr elements.
2135|         if (Field->getType()->isIncompleteArrayType() ||
2136|             ILEElement == ILE->getNumInits())
2137|           break;
2138|         if (Field->isUnnamedBitField())
2139|           continue;
2140| 
2141|         const Expr *E = ILE->getInit(ILEElement++);
2142| 
2143|         // Reference values are always non-null and have the width of a pointer.
2144|         if (Field->getType()->isReferenceType())
2145|           NumNonZeroBytes += CGF.getContext().toCharUnitsFromBits(
2146|               CGF.getTarget().getPointerWidth(LangAS::Default));
2147|         else
2148|           NumNonZeroBytes += GetNumNonZeroBytesInInit(E, CGF);
2149|       }
2150| 
2151|       return NumNonZeroBytes;
2152|     }
2153|   }
2154| 
2155|   // FIXME: This overestimates the number of non-zero bytes for bit-fields.
2156|   CharUnits NumNonZeroBytes = CharUnits::Zero();
2157|   for (unsigned i = 0, e = ILE->getNumInits(); i != e; ++i)
2158|     NumNonZeroBytes += GetNumNonZeroBytesInInit(ILE->getInit(i), CGF);
2159|   return NumNonZeroBytes;
2160| }

We think the following hints might be helpful:
The line 2109 in clang/lib/CodeGen/CGExprAgg.cpp which appears in the stack trace is:
  if (isSimpleZero(E, CGF)) return CharUnits::Zero();

Here are the definitions of the symbols in the line:
1. function isSimpleZero

→ bool
Parameters:
- const Expr * E
- CodeGenFunction & CGF
isSimpleZero - If emitting this value will obviously just cause a store of zero to memory, return true. This can return false if uncertain, so it just handles simple cases.

static bool isSimpleZero(const Expr *E, CodeGenFunction &CGF)
2. param CGF

Type: CodeGenFunction &
Passed by reference as CGF

// In GetNumNonZeroBytesInInit
CodeGenFunction &CGF
3. class CharUnits
provided by "clang/AST/ASTContext.h"

CharUnits - This is an opaque type for sizes expressed in character units.
Instances of this type represent a quantity as a multiple of the size of the standard C type, char, on the target architecture. As an opaque type, CharUnits protects you from accidentally combining operations on quantities in bit units and character units.
In both C and C++, an object of type 'char', 'signed char', or 'unsigned char' occupies exactly one byte, so 'character unit' and 'byte' refer to the same quantity of storage. However, we use the term 'character unit' rather than 'byte' to avoid an implication that a character unit is exactly 8 bits.
For portability, never assume that a target character is 8 bits wide. Use CharUnit values wherever you calculate sizes, offsets, or alignments in character units.

// In namespace clang
class CharUnits {}
4. static-method Zero
provided by "clang/AST/CharUnits.h"

→ CharUnits
Zero - Construct a CharUnits quantity of zero.

// In CharUnits
public: static CharUnits Zero()
